page.title: 18Our Environment
page.content: Our landscape varies from old marsh land to around 5Oft above sea-level. The soil is mainly heavy to clay-like, with some patches of peat. The rises are seldom gentle, and walkers soon realize that the area is anything but level. Much of our area is subject to Listing and Conservation Orders. Enc- losures and hedging were started in l8OO, and are still very much in evi- dence. Wild roses, honeysuckle and blackberries still thrust their way through the elder, hawthorn and may. The Dutch Elms have succumbed to dis- ease, and withies to the levelling work. Copsing and replanting are being done, and a great deal of hardwood is now rooting down. Flag iris, valerian, comfrey, ragged robin, and sedges are common. Recent cuts in spraying have encouraged the old wild flowers and new plantings of hardwood.
